issue.title: G402 should consider Go version
issue.body:
### Summary 
golang/go#45428 landed in Go 1.18, and it sets the default minimum TLS version for clients to 1.2. Because of this, gosec shouldn't flag TLS client config without an explicit minimum version as a problem, as long as the Go version is >= 1.18.

### Steps to reproduce the behavior
Create an HTTP transport with a TLS client config like the following:
```
t := &http.Transport{
	TLSClientConfig: &tls.Config{},
}
```

Run gosec against this code on Go >= 1.18.

### gosec version
v2.15.0

### Go version (output of 'go version')
go version go1.20.2 darwin/arm64

### Operating system / Environment
macOS 13.6

### Expected behavior
gosec doesn't flag the code, as the minimum TLS version for the client is already 1.2 by default.

### Actual behavior
gosec flags the code.

comment.body: @ccojocar is that possible to have a config flag to allow suppress this? We want this as we are fine to use the default TLS 1.2 in the `tls.Config` and we know we will bump go to use the latest version to mitigate any future obsolete issues.

issue.title: Docker image for linux/arm64 contains binary built for linux/amd64
issue.body:
### Summary 

The `linux/arm64` variant of the Docker image uses the wrong target architecture when building the `gosec` binary because it appears to be hardcoded to use `linux/amd64` in the `Makefile`.

https://github.com/securego/gosec/blob/55d79496019a560e16e73e1948dee20a1fad631a/Makefile#L78-L79

You can see this happening in the build output:

https://github.com/securego/gosec/actions/runs/6610375096/job/17952178215#step:13:613

### Steps to reproduce the behavior

Try to run the Docker image on an `aarch64` Linux host.

### gosec version

2.18.2

### Go version (output of 'go version')

N/A

### Operating system / Environment

Linux aarch64

### Expected behavior

Calling `docker run` with the `gosec` image on a Linux `aarch64` host should work.

### Actual behavior

```
$ uname -m
aarch64
$ docker run -it --rm securego/gosec:2.18.2
/bin/entrypoint.sh: line 11: /bin/gosec: cannot execute binary file: Exec format error
$ docker run -it --rm --entrypoint /bin/sh securego/gosec:2.18.2
# readelf -h /bin/gosec | grep Machine
  Machine:                           Advanced Micro Devices X86-64
```

comment.body: Alright, I removed the hardcoded GOOS value. Hopefully next release should work on ARM.

commits.message:
Remove the hardcoded GOOS value when building the Linux binary to enable support for container image for ARM

Signed-off-by: Cosmin Cojocar <gcojocar@adobe.com>

issue.title: Docker image for linux/arm64 contains binary built for linux/amd64
issue.body:
### Summary 

The `linux/arm64` variant of the Docker image uses the wrong target architecture when building the `gosec` binary because it appears to be hardcoded to use `linux/amd64` in the `Makefile`.

https://github.com/securego/gosec/blob/55d79496019a560e16e73e1948dee20a1fad631a/Makefile#L78-L79

You can see this happening in the build output:

https://github.com/securego/gosec/actions/runs/6610375096/job/17952178215#step:13:613

### Steps to reproduce the behavior

Try to run the Docker image on an `aarch64` Linux host.

### gosec version

2.18.2

### Go version (output of 'go version')

N/A

### Operating system / Environment

Linux aarch64

### Expected behavior

Calling `docker run` with the `gosec` image on a Linux `aarch64` host should work.

### Actual behavior

```
$ uname -m
aarch64
$ docker run -it --rm securego/gosec:2.18.2
/bin/entrypoint.sh: line 11: /bin/gosec: cannot execute binary file: Exec format error
$ docker run -it --rm --entrypoint /bin/sh securego/gosec:2.18.2
# readelf -h /bin/gosec | grep Machine
  Machine:                           Advanced Micro Devices X86-64
```

comment.body:
OK, fair enough but the release pipeline appears to be configured to build a Docker image that specifically includes the `linux/arm64` platform target:

https://github.com/securego/gosec/blob/64bbe901441ed79664986b3d056558b256af07d9/.github/workflows/release.yml#L62-L66

And this is published to DockerHub:

```
❯ docker manifest inspect securego/gosec:2.18.2
...
      {
         "mediaType": "application/vnd.oci.image.manifest.v1+json",
         "size": 1626,
         "digest": "sha256:9ff79cda20791835aef381554b62075d787145d5daed8a16b89d59fc29418f03",
         "platform": {
            "architecture": "arm64",
            "os": "linux"
         }
      },
...
```

comment.body: We don't support ARM on docker image. It is built only for x86-64. Please feel free to contribute this if you need it. Thank you

issue.title: G402 (CWE-295): TLS min version false positive on client usage
issue.body:
### Summary 

Go 1.18 has set the default minimum TLS version to TLS 1.2 **for client usage** (commit: https://github.com/golang/go/commit/035963c7f5d82b5bf1501f407919031f815bd038 / proposal: https://github.com/golang/go/issues/45428) . However, in current gosec implementation, it's still taking the default value as `0x0000`, which results in false positive:

```
[<redacted>/gosec-tls-config.go:9] - G402 (CWE-295): TLS MinVersion too low. (Confidence: HIGH, Severity: HIGH)
    8: func main() {
  > 9: 	config := &tls.Config{}
    10:
```

I understand this might have technically difficulties on detecting if the tls config usage is for client or server. But giving program compiled after Go 1.18, the client will always use >= TLS 1.2 to talk to server, I assume it's fine to not marking it as `TLS MinVersion too low` for default settings?

### Steps to reproduce the behavior

Can reproduce with the sample program from this gist: https://gist.github.com/bcho/f1cec099f0d55ca8e90da3fde7cddabb

### gosec version

Latest master commit (64bbe901441ed79664986b3d056558b256af07d9)

### Go version (output of 'go version')

go version go1.21.0 darwin/arm64

### Operating system / Environment

Mac / Linux

### Expected behavior

Not reporting G402 for default configuration in `MinVersion` field.

### Actual behavior

Reporting G402.
